facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2024 and 2025 of 1972 are before the court by certificate raising common questions of law.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2024 and 2025 of 1972. K. Daphtary, R. C. Misra, Advocate-General for the State of Orissa, Santosh Chat

facts.text: The 1st respondent in Civil Appeal No. 2024 of 1971 carries on the business of selling country liquor.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent in Civil Appeal No. 2024 of 1971 is carrying on the business of selling country liquor. In pursuance of the order made by the State of O

facts.text: Excise Commissioner notified on January 8, 1971 that exclusive privilege of selling country liquor retail in eight specified shops in Cuttack District for April 1, 1971 to March 31, 1972 will be sold by public auction on February 15, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the order made by the State of Orissa, the Excise Commissioner notified on January 8, 1971 that the exclusive privilege of selling by retail the country liquor in the eight specified shops in the Cuttack District for the period from April 1, 1971 to March 31, 1972 will be sold by public auction on February 15, 1971 and on the following days.

facts.text: Auction was held on the notified day February 15, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: and on the following days. The auction was accordingly held on the notified day. The 1st respondent was the highest bidder for those eight shops.

facts.text: The 1st respondent was the highest bidder for those eight shops.

anchor.surface_text: The auction was accordingly held on the notified day. The 1st respondent was the highest bidder for those eight shops. His bids were provisionally accepted by the Collector subject to confirmation by the Government.

facts.text: Bids of the 1st respondent were provisionally accepted by the Collector subject to confirmation by the Government.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent was the highest bidder for those eight shops. His bids were provisionally accepted by the Collector subject to confirmation by the Government. The Government rejected those bids being of the view that inadequate price had been offered as a result of collusion between the bidders.

facts.text: Government rejected the bids viewing inadequate price due to collusion between bidders.

anchor.surface_text: His bids were provisionally accepted by the Collector subject to confirmation by the Government. The Government rejected those bids being of the view that inadequate price had been offered as a result of collusion between the bidders. It ordered the Excise Commissioner to call for tenders in respect of those shops.

facts.text: Government ordered Excise Commissioner to call for tenders in respect of those shops.

anchor.surface_text: The Government rejected those bids being of the view that inadequate price had been offered as a result of collusion between the bidders. It ordered the Excise Commissioner to call for tenders in respect of those shops. After the tenders were duly received, the Government accepted the tender in respect of one shop and rejected the other tenders as it was again of the opinion that the price offered was inadequate.

facts.text: After tenders received, Government accepted tender for one shop and rejected others as inadequate price.

anchor.surface_text: It ordered the Excise Commissioner to call for tenders in respect of those shops. After the tenders were duly received, the Government accepted the tender in respect of one shop and rejected the other tenders as it was again of the opinion that the price offered was inadequate. Thereafter it sold the seven shops by negotiating with some of the tenderers.

facts.text: Government sold the seven shops by negotiating with some tenderers at substantially higher price.

anchor.surface_text: the Government accepted the tender in respect of one shop and rejected the other tenders as it was again of the opinion that the price offered was inadequate. Thereafter it sold the seven shops by negotiating with some of the tenderers. The price ultimately fetched was substantially more than that offered either at the auction or as per tenders.

facts.text: 1st respondent moved High Court of Orissa under Art. 226 for direction to Government to confirm his bids and issue licences.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter it sold the seven shops by negotiating with some of the tenderers. The price ultimately fetched was substantially more than that offered either at the auction or as per tenders. Thereafter the 1st respondent moved the, High Court of Orissa under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a direction to the Government to confirm his bids and cause the necessary licences to be issued to him.

facts.text: High Court held that Government had no power to refuse to confirm bids of highest bidders except on good grounds and grounds relied on were irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the Government had no power to refuse to confirm the bids of the highest bidders except on good grounds and the ground that had commended itself to the Government for refusing to confirm the bids were irrelevant.

facts.text: High Court opined absolute power to confirm or refuse highest bids without reason is unguided and violative of Arts. 14 and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: It also opined that the absolute power conferred on the Government to confirm or refuse to confirm the highest bids without giving any reason was an unguided power and consequently by violative of Arts. 14 and 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court opined monetary considerations irrelevant for confirming highest bid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was further of the opinion that monetary considerations were irrelevant for deciding the question whether the highest bid should be confirmed or not.

facts.text: State of Orissa appealed to Supreme Court against High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by that decision, the State of Orissa has come up in appeal. Before proceeding to pronounce on the contentions advanced at the hearing, it is convenient to set out the relevant provisions of law as well as the orders passed by the Government under S. 29 of the Bihar and Orissa Excise Act, 1915  as amended upto October 6, 1970   to be hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: State Government issued order on January 6, 1971 under s.29(2) directing sums for privilege determined by auction.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by s. 29 2  of the Act, the State Government issued an order on January 6, 1971 directing that any sum payable under the aforesaid section for grant of the exclusive privilege of manufacturing and selling by retail of country liquor shall, unless otherwise directed by the State Government, in any particular case or cases for any reason, be determined by auction to be held in accordance with the procedure specified below

facts.text: Collector held auction in respect of the shops; highest bidder made necessary deposits but Government did not accept bids.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier in pursuance of the above order, the Collector held an auction in respect of the shops mentioned earlier. The highest bidder had made the necessary deposits. But. the Government did not accept his bids.

facts.text: On March 7, 1971, Government issued order directing tenders due to collusive bids at auction.

anchor.surface_text: On March 7, 1971, the Government issued the following order Whereas for determining the sums payable for the grant of exclusive privilege of manufacturing and selling by retail of country liquor auction had been held in the district of Cuttack in accordance with the procedure laid down in the order of the Government of Orissa in the Excise Department No. S.R.O. 12/71, dated the 6th January 1971 Whereas due to collusive bids among the bidders at the said auction it is not possible to determine the said sums in the aforesaid manner

facts.text: Government accepted tender for only one shop and sold others by negotiation.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier, the Government accepted the tender in respect of only one shop and sold the exclusive privilege to sell country liquor in other shops by negotiation.

facts.text: Writ petitioners did not challenge validity of provisions in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Before us the writ petitioners did not challenge the validity of any of the provisions in the Act possibly in their own interest. They are not interested in raising any contention which might vitiate the auctions held.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeals and dismissed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: In the result these appeals are allowed and the writ petitions dismissed. No costs.

issues.text: Whether the power retained by the Government to accept or reject any bid without assigning any reason in cl. 6 of the order dated January 6, 1971 under s. 29(2) of the Act is an arbitrary power violative of Articles 14 and 19(1)(g) of the Constitution
Whether there is a fundamental right under Article 19(1)(g) to carry on trade in country liquor and whether the restrictions imposed are reasonable

anchor.surface_text: violative of Arts. 14 and 19  1   g  of the Constitution. The High Court was further of the opinion that monetary considerations were irrelevant for deciding the question whether the highest bid should be confirmed or not.

issues.text: Whether having recourse to auction once, the Government is precluded from calling tenders or selling by negotiation
Whether the Government is required to make a specific order under s.29(2)(a) before selling privileges by private negotiation

arguments.claim: Power to accept/reject highest bid without reason is unguided and violative of Art.14

anchor.surface_text: It was further urged that the power retained by the Government to accept or to reject the highest bid without assigning any reason is an unguided power and hence it is violative of Art. 14.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: useless. Similar is the effect when the Government refused to accept the highest tender. That left the Government free to have recourse to other metho

arguments.court_reasoning: Power statutory, by highest authority, for revenue; arbitrary only if collateral purpose

arguments.claim: Having had recourse to auction method once, Government precluded from calling tenders or selling by negotiation
arguments.court_reasoning: Rejecting bids makes auction useless; s.29 allows any method including otherwise; wide power unrestricted

arguments.claim: Before selling by private negotiation, Government required to make specific order under s.29(2)(a) directing that privileges will be sold by private negotiation

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that before adopting the method of selling the privileges by private negotiation. The Government is required by S. 29  2   a  to make an order that the, privileges in question will be sold by private negotiation.

arguments.court_reasoning: No order needed for govt acting itself via negotiation; s.29(2)(a) directions to subordinates for auctions/tenders; makes no sense for self-direction

arguments.claim: Sections 22 and 29 confer absolute power on State Government to grant exclusive privilege and determine payment by auction, tenders or otherwise

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier s. 22 of the Act confers power on the Government to grant to any person on such conditions and for such period as it may think fit the exclusive privilege of selling in retail any country liquor.

arguments.claim: Cl.6 of Jan 6 order reserving power to accept/reject bids without reason is not more than statutory power under ss.22/29; cannot challenge order without challenging Act

anchor.surface_text: The power that the government reserved for itself under that clause is nothing more than what was conferred on it by the legislature under s. 22 and s. 29 of the Act.

arguments.claim: No inherent right to sell liquor; state power to prohibit injurious trade; auction fee is revenue raising per precedents Cooverjee Bharucha and Krishna Kumar Narula

anchor.surface_text: It is true that this Court has ruled that the right to trade in intoxicating drugs is also a right to carry on any trade or business within the meaning of Art. 19  1   g  see Krishna Kumar Narula

arguments.claim: Govt decision on bid adequacy is executive function to protect revenue, not open to judicial review unless mala fide

anchor.surface_text: It is for the. Government to decide whether the price offered in an auction sale is adequate. While accepting or rejecting a bid, it is merely performing an executive function. The correctness of its conclusion is not open to judicial review.

arguments.claim: No concluded contract or vested right till bid confirmed by govt; bidders can withdraw before

anchor.surface_text: There is no concluded contract till the bid is accepted. Before there was a concluded contract, it was open to the bidders to withdraw their bids-see Union of India and ors. v. M s. Bhimsen Walaiti Ram

arguments.claim: Govt as exclusive owner of privileges; no fundamental right to trade in govt property at inadequate price; no Art.14/19 violation

anchor.surface_text: If the Government is the exclusive owner of those privileges, reliance on Art. 19 1  g  or Art. 14 becomes irrelevant. Citizens cannot have any fundamental right to trade or carry on business in the properties or rights belonging to the Government

arguments.claim: Power exercised by highest authority (Govt) safeguarding state finances cannot be arbitrary unless for collateral purpose

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the question of arbitrary or unguided power can arise in a case of this nature, it should not be forgotten that the power to accept or reject the highest bid is given to the highest authority in the State i.e. the Government

arguments.claim: Govt not required to prove collusion or satisfy court on bid inadequacy; its inference not reviewable unless mala fide
Once govt declines highest bid, auction useless; free to adopt other methods under wide power of s.29 including negotiation

anchor.surface_text: Once the Government declines to accept the highest bid, the auction held became useless. Similar is the effect when the Government refused to accept the highest tender. That left the Government free to have recourse to other methods.

arguments.claim: No specific order under s.29(2)(a) required for private negotiation as govt acts itself, unlike auctions/tenders by subordinates

holdings.text: The powers conferred on the State Government by s. 22 and s. 29 are absolute powers.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of ss.22 and 29 granting wide discretion to govt for grant of privileges and determination of sums by auction, tenders or otherwise without limitations.

holdings.text: The power reserved under clause 6 of the order dated January 6, 1971 is nothing more than the statutory power under ss.22 and 29 and cannot be challenged without challenging the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 6 reflects legislative conferment; no additional arbitrary power; petitioners did not challenge Act provisions.

holdings.text: The Government performs an executive function in deciding bid adequacy, the correctness of which is not open to judicial review.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Govt guards state revenue; decision on commercial adequacy is policy/executive, reviewable only for mala fides or collateral purpose.

holdings.text: We fail to see how the plea of contravention of Art. 19(1)(g) or Art. 14 can arise in these cases.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No fundamental right to trade in govt privileges at inadequate price; state monopoly over liquor trade; revenue protection valid.

holdings.text: There is no concluded contract till the bid is accepted; no vested right acquired by highest bidder before confirmation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisional acceptance subject to govt confirmation; contract law principles apply; cites precedent.

holdings.text: Power to accept or reject highest bid given to highest authority (Government) expected to safeguard state finances cannot be considered arbitrary unless exercised for collateral purpose.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power by legislature to executive head for revenue; not unguided; obiter assuming arguendo.

holdings.text: The Government was not bound to satisfy the Court that there was collusion; inference of collusion or inadequacy not open to judicial review unless mala fide.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not appellate over executive inference on facts/revenue; limited review standard.

holdings.text: Once the Government declines to accept the highest bid, the auction becomes useless and Government is free to have recourse to other methods including negotiation.

anchor.surface_text: Once the Government declines to accept the highest bid, the auction held became useless. Similar is the effect when the Government refused to accept the highest tender. That left the Government free to have recourse to other methods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide power under s.29 'or otherwise'; rejection resets process; no estoppel.

holdings.text: No specific order under s.29(2)(a) is required before Government sells privileges by private negotiation as it acts itself, unlike directions to subordinates for auctions/tenders.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive reading: s.29(2)(a) for directing officers; self-negotiation needs no self-order; reasonable construction.

holdings.text: One of the important purposes of ss.22 and 29 is to raise revenue; monetary considerations are relevant for bid confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: As held by this Court in Cooverjee Bharuchas case supra , one of the important purpose of selling the exclusive right to sell liquor in wholesale or retail is to raise revenue. Excise revenue forms an important part of every States revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition of excise revenue includes s.29 payments; precedents confirm revenue-raising via auctions.

The Excise Commissioner and the Chief Commissioner, Ajmer and ors.  2  that for determining reasonable restrictions within the meaning of Art 19  6  of the Constitution on the right given under cl. 19  1   g  regard must be had to the nature of the business and the conditions prevailing in a particular trade State has power to prohibit trades which are illegal or immoral or injurious to the health and  1  1967 3 S.C.R. 50.  2  1954 S.C.R. 873. welfare of the public and there is no inherent right in a citizen to sell intoxicating liquors by retail.

precedents.case_name: Cooverjee B. Bharucha v. The Excise Commissioner and the Chief Commissioner, Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: for determining reasonable restrictions within the meaning of Art 19(6) regard must be had to the nature of the business; State has power to prohibit injurious trades; no inherent right to sell intoxicating liquors by retail; provisions regulating trade in liquor valid; licence fee by auction is tax for revenue
